summary: Alan G. Sentinella was a retired FBI Special Agent who testified before the Senate Select Committee (SSC) in May and June of 1975. His testimony primarily concerned FBI investigations into Martin Luther King Jr., the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC), and Stanley Levison. The documents indicate that Sentinella's testimony covered topics such as electronic surveillance, potential communist influence, and the FBI's operational policies during these investigations. He provided recollections and details about his involvement in these investigations, focusing on telephone surveillance and alleged communist connections. The documents consistently refer to his testimony before the SSC regarding the aforementioned investigations.
significance: While the documents do not directly link Alan G. Sentinella to the JFK assassination, his testimony before the Senate Select Committee (SSC) on Intelligence Activities, which was investigating various matters including potential abuses of power by intelligence agencies, is relevant to the broader historical context of the time. The SSC's work was part of a larger effort to understand the activities and potential overreach of government agencies, which could indirectly relate to aspects surrounding the JFK assassination and its investigation.
